description:
Sweat Punch is a series of five Studio 4°C shorts collected as a direct-to-DVD package film entitled Deep Imagination.

1. Tanpetori Kyouju no Yuuutsu (タンペトリー教授の憂鬱, Professor Dan Petory's Blues)
A musical number starring a hand puppet named Junior. The puppet is controlled by the drunken Professor Dan Petory who explains in puppetry the answers to such questions as why the Earth is blue and why UFOs fly in a zig-zag pattern.

2. End of the World
"End of the World" is a science fiction story about a young alien girl named Yuko as she escapes from the world of humans. After meeting Kazumi, a human girl Yuko met at a rock concert, the girls head to Kazumi's apartment. Before Yuko even takes off her shoes, however, she leaves through Kazumi's TV with her trusty cybernetic steed FACE to wage a retaliatory campaign against hordes of S&M monsters from another dimension, and the evil queen of Yuko's world.

3. Kigeki (喜劇, Comedy)
Set during the Irish War of Independence, a five-year old girl goes out in search of the mysterious Demon’s Castle - home of the Black Knight whose services she hopes to recruit. The Black Knight is a dark, young, skilled swordsman who will only accept a particular genre of books as advance payment.

4. Higan (彼岸, Enlightenment)
An injured man lies completely still in a hospital room with doctors hovering at his bedside, appearing serene and peaceful as he slowly succumbs to death. However, in his own mind, memories of a recent battle vividly flash by. Thoughts of death and chaos haunt him, even in his final moments.

5. Garakuta no Machi (ガラクタの町, Junk Town)
One summer day, a young boy encounters a little robot at a shopping arcade-a hungry little robot, it turns out, as he devours one machine after the other, growing in size with each "meal". This story of a boy, a machine, and their little adventure is the tale of an unusual friendship, enriched by the details of daily life and seen through the director's unique visual style.

(Source: Studio 4°C website)
synonyms: タンペトリー教授の憂鬱

node.description:
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/osamukoba) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/小林治_(イラストレーター%29) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osamu_Kobayashi_(illustrator%29)

Osamu Kobayashi was a Japanese director, animator, illustrator and designer, noted for having directed shows such as [Beck](https://anilist.co/anime/57/), [Paradise Kiss](https://anilist.co/anime/322/) and [Someday's Dreamers II](https://anilist.co/anime/4483/). After graduating from high school, he worked as a mangaka and designer, but following his participation in the video game Grandia as a designer, he was mainly active in the field of animation.

Kobayashi passed away due to kidney cancer on April 17, 2021.

Brother of [Makoto Kobayashi](https://anilist.co/staff/117729/).

_Note: Not to be confused with the 1945 born director, [Osamu Kobayashi](https://anilist.co/staff/105374/)._

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/osamukoba) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/小林治_(イラストレーター%29) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osamu_Kobayashi_(illustrator%29)

Osamu Kobayashi was a Japanese director, animator, illustrator and designer, noted for having directed shows such as [Beck](https://anilist.co/anime/57/), [Paradise Kiss](https://anilist.co/anime/322/) and [Someday's Dreamers II](https://anilist.co/anime/4483/). After graduating from high school, he worked as a mangaka and designer, but following his participation in the video game Grandia as a designer, he was mainly active in the field of animation.

Kobayashi passed away due to kidney cancer on April 17, 2021.

Brother of [Makoto Kobayashi](https://anilist.co/staff/117729/).

_Note: Not to be confused with the 1945 born director, [Osamu Kobayashi](https://anilist.co/staff/105374/)._

Aspired to become an animator simply because he wanted to draw for a living. Later enrolled to and graduated from Tokyo Animator Gakuin. He then joined [Magic Bus](https://anilist.co/studio/207/) and debuted as an in-betweener in 1987 under the studio's name on [God Bless Dancougar](https://anilist.co/anime/5266/). Nakazawa soon left Magic Bus and went freelance. In 1993, he was involved in the establishment of Studio G-1, an animation studio founded by [Masami Oobari](https://anilist.co/staff/100660/). During his time there he participated in many of [AIC](https://anilist.co/studio/48/)'s productions. Nakazawa got strongly influenced by Oobari during this time due to working under him on multiple occasions. Also unlike most animators at the time, Nakazawa wasn't really that shaped by [Yoshinori Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/)'s style, he was though, a huge fan of [Ichirou Itano](https://anilist.co/staff/103268/)'s and [Yoshikazu Yasuhiko](https://anilist.co/staff/97220/)'s.

In 2002, Nakazawa made his directorial debut with Comedy, part of an anthology titled [Sweat Punch](https://anilist.co/anime/1072/), produced by [Studio 4°C](https://anilist.co/studio/13/). The following year he directed both [Parasite Dolls](https://anilist.co/anime/1350/) jointly with [Naoyuki Yoshinaga](https://anilist.co/staff/115038/), as well as the animated part in Quentin Tarantino's movie, Kill Bill: Volume 1. This brought him a lot of international praise. He then got reached out to by director [Shinichirou Watanabe](https://anilist.co/staff/97009/) of [Cowboy Bebop](https://anilist.co/anime/1/) fame, about the possiblity of taking part in the director's next work, [Samurai Champloo](https://anilist.co/anime/205/). Nakazawa accepted the offer and ended up being a crucial part of its production, handling the character designs and serving as the sole chief animation director on the show. He also directed, storyboarded and wrote the 15th episode. Ten years later in 2014, Nakazawa collaborated with Watanabe for the second time on [Terror in Resonance](https://anilist.co/anime/20661/), providing the character designs and working as an animation director on the series.

In recent years he has been closely involved with [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/kantakamei) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/亀井幹太)

Adept in various fields related to computer graphics.

Close friends with [Kazuto Nakazawa](https://anilist.co/staff/101474/).

The president of Studio 4°C, an animation studio she founded with Koji Morimoto and Yoshiharu Sato in 1986. Tanaka is also the chief executive officer of a production company called Beyond C, which initiated the project with Michael Arias that became Tekkon Kinkreet. 

Tanaka was an executive producer on Tekkon Kinkreet and Mind Game, both Studio 4°C films. She was also an animation producer on Beyond and The Second Renaissance Part 1 for the Animatrix project. Tanaka previously worked with Studio Ghibli and played the role of line producer on My Neighbor Totoro and Kiki's Delivery Service.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E4%BC%8A%E6%9D%B1%E4%BC%B8%E9%AB%98)

Best known for his individual designs outside of the industry's norm.

Originating from Studio Dove. Itou started as an in-betweener on [Zettai Muteki Raijin Ou](https://anilist.co/anime/1897/) and made his debut as a character designer on the series [Kemonozume](https://anilist.co/anime/1454/), directed by [Masaaki Yuasa](https://anilist.co/staff/100068/). He has since designed the characters for most of Yuasa's works.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/01_chan)

He graduated from Yoyogi Animation school and joined Studio Junio afterwards. After leaving Studio Junio, he became a freelancer and often works with Studio Sunrise and GONZO.
In 2008, him and former GONZO producer Ikeda Touyo founded Encourage Films Co., Ltd, with a capital of 5 million yen.
Ikeda Touyo would serve as the representative director and president of Encourage Films. 
With the death of Ikeda Touyo, on February 17, 2013, he was appointed as the representative director and CEO of Encourage Films.
